visibilitywas less than a mile.
Then he turned to come back. At
while he might
He had the misfortune to come out of his turn at the edge
of & local fog bank that surrounded a high island.
He
did not see
the fog bank and he flew right into it, and struck the island an
instant later.
I do not
for a moment deny that the crash was avoidable, but
in my judgement it was excusable under the conditions
that prevailed.
Undoubtedly the pilot was endeavouring to use his best judgement.
It is fairly evident that his judgement must have been at fault as
to the amount of visibility available.
With a visibility of a mile
he should certainly have been able to detect fog before running into
it, therefore we reason that his visibility must have been conside-
less
than a mile.
But the usual facilities available to a
pilot for checking visibility were lacking in this case.
I therefore
do not feel that it would be
fair or correct to say that the pilot
deliberately proceeded in weather which he knew offered less than
a mile of visibility.
Rumill is as careful and
conservative a pilot as I have ever
known.
He is incapable of a,lie and has made no attempt to alibi
himself out of any
possible blame.
He will remain grounded until
you cable us your decision.
My own recommendation is that he be reinstated in our service.
Every
passenger from the crash has expressed an admiration for him
and for his actions during and immediately after the crash, and
have publicly stated their desire to fly with him again.
I sincerely hope you will not think me unduly sympathetic in
this case.
If I felt that Rumill had deliberately broken
our
safety rules, and thereby risked the lives of passengers in his care,
of faot, it is difficult for me
more than he deserves, for the reason that the effect of this crash
is so destructive to our plans and hopes.
We had the entire
confidence of the public from here to Manila,
as well as their strong
interest and goodwill. Now we have lost a lot of that.
A lot of
people in our home company will
probably feel that I don't know my
That would be only natural and there is nothing I can say.
that you know and understand
make this line as thoroughly Pan American as is the Caribbean Division
in spirit and in actual operating methods.
If you believe
feel certain that he is thoroughly deserving•
Since the orash I have been doing Rumill's share
of the flying
and it is difficult for me to spare that much time.
If you will
please cable your decision in this matter we will appreciate it
very much.
With kindest regards,
W. S. Grooch
d 118015l

Deb- Just for your
stur
Own in fou Shanghal, December 18th 1933.
CONF IDENT TAL
Chief Engineer,
New York.
Dear Mr. Priester,
gant
The board forwarded
its report on the crash
01 NC16V
last night.
The report
contains my own testimony
which sets forth my
estimate of the situation.
I have little
to add
to the report
except my profound regret that our efforts
to build up a safe
and dependable air service in China should
meet
such & handicap
in its very inception.
our personnel are loyal and
intensely
interested in our work.
proposition
to fly with an old experienced pilot and criticise his handling
of the plane, or his navigation, without incurring a certain
amount of resentment.
But these pilote have accepted my suggestions
and
criticism cheerfully and have assisted our work to the limit
of their ability.
After flying the line with Rumill several times I was thoroughly
convinced of his ability as a pilot and his safe anô
conservative
jud gement.
This is the first crash he has ever had in sixteen years
of flying and it has nearly broken his heart.
I have gone over and
over with him and with Ehmer the conditions leading up to the crash.
and while it appears evident that he should have turned back sooner.
I am thoroughlyconvinced that when he made the turn to come back
ho was perfectly certain of his ability to see any obstruction in
plenty of time to avoid it.
The one point that he overlooked was
that if he should meet a local fog area under the conditions that
prevailed, it would blend
in with
the yellow color of the bay and
he would not see it in time to avoid it.
Granted that it was a
mistake in judgement, it was brought about by most unusual conditions
and although all of us have flown across that bay a dozen times we
have had no previous indication of such a condition.
From all
testimony available it is clearly evident that Rumill, knowing that
there was clear weather ahead and behind, felt that he had nothing
to worry about except a hazy condition over the bay.
Once he
picked up the coast line on the other side of the bay he could
definitely check his visibility.
He had a full load of passengers
for this inaugural passenger flight and had been forced to turn
back once before. Confident that he was able to see obstructions
he proceeded until he became convinced by the fact that the ceiling
was dropping and his view of the water getting dimmer, that his
